Budget Summary Overview

<<Budget>>

Click on the purple number to see some options for this amount. There are multiple ways to move money around your budget. After all, it's meant to be flexible!

<<Budget>>

Let's move onto the next part!
Budget Table Overview

<<Budget>>

This is the budget table, basically a digital cash envelope system! You create categories relevant to your life and budget dollars accordingly.

<<Budget>>

The Category column houses the names of each category. We'll customize these for your life in a bit.

<<Budget>>

The Budgeted column is where you'll be budgeting your dollars. This shows you what you have allocated each month for the categories.

<<Budget>>

Next up is the Spent column. This shows you what you've actually spent out of the budgeted dollars. 

This column will automatically update when you assign categories to transactions on the Accounts page.

<<Budget>>

We spoke about the Budgeted and Spent columns. The last column is Balance. This shows you what you have available to spend. If it's negative and red, you've overspent in this category. If the amount is black, that's what you have available. 

Remember, you can address the overspend (red) numbers by shifting money left (black) in other categories.

<<Budget>>

If you don't cover this overspending, you either risk over-drafting your bank account or adding debt to your credit card.

<<Budget>>

To the left of the header 'Category' at the top of the Budget Table, select the three dots. This gives you visual options. You can show and hide hidden categories and collapse or expand Category Groups.

<<Budget>>

When you hover over a row, an arrow appears. The rows in 'Grey' that have bold text are called 'Category Groups.' The arrow in a Category Group row has options to add a category in this group, hide it, rename it or delete it.

<<Budget>>

How to move money (Option 1)

1) Select the To Budget number                    
2) Select "Move to a category"                       
3) Enter the amount you would like to move  
4) Choose the category in the "To" dropdown
5) Select "Transfer"

<<Budget>>

If you are starting in middle of month or end of month, you do not need to budget for dollars already spent or not needed. 

For example, if it is the 10th of the month today then you don't need to budget your entire month of groceries since there are are only about 20 days left in the month.

<<Budget>>

It's best to first budget dollars to future expenses that will come out of your checking account prior to you being paid again. For example: Car Payment; Mortgage/Rent; Utility payments...

<<Budget>>

The rows below a Category Group row, not shaded grey and not bold text, are called Categories. When you hover over a Category row, the arrow that appears gives you the option to Hide, Rename, and Delete that Category.

<<Budget>>

Below the categories is the 'Income' Section.

<<Budget>>

The Income row is the total amount of deposits to a checking or savings account in a month. 

The Starting Balances row is calculated your first month, but then remains $0 each month after that. You can 'Hide' this category if you choose after your first month.
move_to: received_column

<<Budget>>

Also when you hover on a Category row, a small paper icon appears. Selecting this opens up a note box. This can be used to capture helpful information about that category. For example, the amount you intend to budget each month, or when it is due, if not due monthly.

<<Budget>>

When you hover over the month at the top of the budget summary, two up arrows are shown to the left. Selecting this will collapse the budget summary view to only show the 'To Budget' amount.

You can expand by hovering over the month and then selecting the two now down arrows to the left of the month.

<<Budget>>

To the right of the month there are three vertical dots. Selecting this shows additional options that can have dollars budgeted to all your categories in one click.

<<Budget>>

These options include:

1. Copy last month's budget
2. Set budgets to zero
3. Set budgets to 3 month average

That's right!

<<Budget>>

Essentially, you are only budgeting with the money you have available in the present. This is done by assigning each dollar a job (or category) until you get to $0 left to budget.
 
There are a few benefits of this method of budgeting. You may be familiar with some of them.

<<Budget>>

Greater financial awareness - by consciously assigning each dollar to a category, you can be confident in your spending decisions

<<Budget>>

Reduces the chance of falling into debt - by giving each dollar a job, you will know whether or not you have the cash on hand to buy that thing.

<<Budget>>

Flexibility - Flexibility with a budget? Aren't budgets supposed to be rigid and unforgiving? These are popular myths about budgets but using this system can actually provide you with greater flexibility while making responsible financial decisions.

<<Budget>>

Well if you don't have the money in a specific category to make a purchase, you can actually move money from one category to another. Put another way- you can move "cash" at anytime from the restaurant envelope to the vacation envelope.
Let's see how it works!

<<Budget>>

Of course, by doing so you are making the decision to spend less in the category you are moving money out of. Budgets can be flexible and adaptive!

<<Budget>>

Do you already know the category groups and categories you want in your budget?

<<Budget>>

Fresh start - The past is in the past. You are here today. You set the budget on your terms with the money you have available. What you did yesterday or last year is already done. Now, you get to budget based on your current needs and priorities.

<<Budget>>


That's great! I love your enthusiasm. Before you do, I just want to share a couple pointers.

<<Budget>>


You want to make sure you have appropiate categories that relate to your expenses and your life. Expenses generally fall into some of the following categories.

<<Budget>>


  Fixed vs. Variable

Fixed expenses don't change frequently such as rent, mortgage, or subscriptions.

Variable expenses vary period to period such as the electric bill, gas or food.
Dealing with non-recurring expenses

<<Budget>>


  Recurring vs. Non-recurring

Recurring expenses happen with some predictable frequency such as rent / mortgage or annual holiday shopping.

Non-recurring expenses are hard to predict if or when they will happen and sometimes even how much. Unsurprisingly, these are the type of expenses that can derail an otherwise perfect budget.

<<Budget>>


Non-recurring expenses could include emergencies, replacing a car, home maintenance, surprise medical bill, vacation, down payment, etc. 

You can try setting aside some money every month for the non-recurring expenses possibly relevant to your life. Saving a little each month can go a long way when you have an unanticipated expense pop up.

<<Budget>>


You can also structure a budget into needs and wants.

<<Budget>>

It can be overwhelming with so many ways to structure a budget. But that's why I'm here- to help you in your budgeting journey!

Reveal #1

<<Budget>>

Here are two of my favorite features on this screen.

<<Budget>>

MBC can do math for you!

For example, type 33.80 into the budgeted column for any category. 

Now type "+72.25" (without quotes) after the 33.80 and press enter. It will now say 106.50 for the Budgeted amount.

Don't forget to set this number back to what it was.
Reveal #2

MyBudgetCoach has a unique feature that is called 'Rollover overspending.' This option allows a user to have the debt continue into future months, instead of paying off this month, so you can pay it off overtime.

<<Accounts>>

Thanks for that information. Direct Import within MyBudgetCoach has some great benefits. For example, the starting balance for linked accounts is automatically set and the system includes three prior days worth of transactions to get you started.

<<Accounts>>

Direct Import removes the additional tasks of having to manually upload transactions. Each time you log in, the system will automatically have added recent transactions.

<<Accounts>>

MyBudgetCoach uses machine learning, so as you continue to use the system, the system will automatically apply proposed categories to new transactions and the manual steps to categorize transactions will lessen over time.

<<Accounts>>

To increase your security, MyBudgetCoach has partnered with a third-party service, SimpleFIN, to link your accounts. SimpleFIN uses a well-established connection software called 'MX' to connect your bank account financial institutions to SimpleFIN.

<<Accounts>>

To connect SimpleFIN to MyBudgetCoach, there is a one-time code produced by SimpleFIN to enter into MyBudgetCoach. The accounts you link in SimpleFIN will then become available to link to already existing accounts within MyBudgetCoach to start Direct Import.

<<Accounts>>

Please note SimpleFIN does have a small additional fee: $1.50 per month, or $15 per year (not including tax, if applicable). This is paid separately from your MyBudgetCoach subscription and is paid through SimpleFIN, not within MyBudgetCoach.

Be sure your columns are organized in the following order:

Date / Payee / Notes / Category (blank) / Amount

The amount can either be one column, or split into separate columns, one for Payments and one for Deposits.

MyBudgetCoach can also split up the amount column into two separate columns by splitting the positive and negative values.

<<Accounts>>

There are three options:

Option 1: Adding transactions manually (the Introduction conversation walked through this process),

Option 2: Direct Import - using a third-party bank connection software, SimpleFIN. Once completed, when you select 'Sync' transactions will automatically be brought into MyBudgetCoach for all accounts.

Option 3: Bulk Import - uploading exports of transactions from your bank to MyBudgetCoach to add transactions in bulk for each account.

Budget Table Overview

<<Budget>>

This is the budget table, basically a digital cash envelope system! You create categories relevant to your life and budget dollars accordingly.

<<Budget>>

The Category column houses the names of each category. We'll customize these for your life in a bit.

<<Budget>>

The Budgeted column is where you'll be budgeting your dollars. This shows you what you have allocated each month for the categories.

<<Budget>>

Next up is the Spent column. This shows you what you've actually spent out of the budgeted dollars. 

This column will automatically update when you assign categories to transactions on the Accounts page.

<<Budget>>

We spoke about the Budgeted and Spent columns. The last column is Balance. This shows you what you have available to spend. If it's negative and red, you've overspent in this category. If the amount is black, that's what you have available. 

Remember, you can address the overspend (red) numbers by shifting money left (black) in other categories.

<<Budget>>

If you don't cover this overspending, you either risk over-drafting your checking account or adding debt to your credit card.

<<Budget>>

To the left of the header 'Category' at the top of the Budget Table, select the three dots. This gives you visual options. You can show and hide hidden categories and collapse or expand Category Groups.

<<Budget>>

When you hover over a row, an arrow appears. The rows in 'Grey' that have bold text are called 'Category Groups.' The arrow in a Category Group row has options to add a category in this group, hide it, rename it or delete it.

That's right!

<<Budget>>

Essentially, you are only budgeting with the money you have available in the present. This is done by assigning each dollar a job (or category) until you get to $0 left to budget.
 
There are a few benefits of this method of budgeting. You may be familiar with some of them.

<<Budget>>

Greater financial awareness - by consciously assigning each dollar to a category, you can be confident in your spending decisions

<<Budget>>

Reduces the chance of falling into debt - by giving each dollar a job, you will now whether or not you have the cash on hand to buy that thing.

<<Budget>>

Flexibility - Flexibility with a budget? Aren't budgets supposed to be rigid and unforgiving? These are popular myths about budgets but using this system can actually provide you with greater flexibility while making responsible financial decisions.

<<Budget>>

Fresh start - The past is in the past. You are here today. You set the budget on your terms with the money you have available. What you did yesterday or last year is already done. Now, you get to budget based on your current needs and priorities.

<<Budget>>


That's great! I love your enthusiasm. Before you do, I just want to share a couple pointers.

<<Budget>>


You want to make sure you have appropiate categories that relate to your expenses and your life. Expenses generally fall into some of the following categories.

<<Budget>>


  Fixed vs. Variable

Fixed expenses don't change frequently such as rent, mortgage, or subscriptions,

Variable expenses vary period to period such as the electric bill, gas or food
Dealing with non-recurring expenses

<<Budget>>


  Recurring vs. Non-recurring

Recurring expenses happen with some predictable frequency such as rent / mortgage or annual holiday shopping.

Non-recurring expenses are hard to predict if or when they will happen and sometimes even how much. Unsurprisingly, these are the type of expenses that can derail an otherwise perfect budget.

<<Budget>>


Non-recurring expenses could include emergencies, replacing a car, home maintenance, surprise medical bill, vacation, down payment, etc. 

You can try setting aside some money every month for the non-recurring expenses possibly relevant to your life. Saving a little each month can go a long way when you have an unanticipated expense pop up.

<<Budget>>


You can also structure a budget into needs and wants.

<<Budget>>

It can be overwhelming with so many ways to structure a budget. But that's why I'm here- to help you in your budgeting journey!

Reveal #1

Here are two of my favorite features on this screen.

<<Budget>>

MBC can do math for you!

For example, type $33.80 into the budgeted column for any category. 

Now type "+72.25" (without quotes) after the 33.80 and press enter. It will now say 106.50 for the Budgeted amount.

Don't forget to set this number back to what it was.
Reveal #2

Pretty cool, right? 

The next feature allows you to drill down into your detail. You may need to come back to this one once you have some transactions entered (or you can enter a test transaction now like we did earlier).
